newsitem.title: CHINA: China's stock indices fall on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: China's stock indices fall on profit-taking.

text.p: China's A and B share indices fell across the board on Friday mainly due to profit-taking on the back of negative rumours, brokers said.
The Shenzhen B share index fell a sharp 3.67 percent to 142.17 points and the A share index slumped 2.46 percent to end at 340.42 points.
In Shanghai, the B index fell 1.58 percent to 64.703 points while the A index dropped 2.17 percent to 937.361.
Among Shanghai-listed A shares, Petroleum Long Champ was the biggest loser, slipping 7.20 percent to 10.30 yuan on institutional profit-taking, .
On the Shenzhen A share market, selling targeted a range of recently-listed issues that had accumulated heavy gains over the past few sessions, brokers said.
Brokers said profit-taking following gains on Thursday pushed the Shenzhen indices down, which also discouraged investors in Shanghai.

Shenzhen brokers said Friday's declines were also due in part to rumours that Chinese patriarch Deng Xiaoping was in fragile health and that Beijing planned to launch a new crackdown on illicit stock trading.
"Investors reduced their positions to see whether there would be any negative news on the weekend," one Shenzhen broker said.
"Falls in the A share market late in the session also triggered domestic individual selling in the B share market," a Shanghai-based broker said.
On the Shenzhen B share market, Great Ocean was the worst performer, falling 6.78 percent to HK$3.85 on profit-taking, brokers said.
In Shanghai, property developer Lujiazui was most the active trade, falling 2.56 percent to US$0.912 on volume of 3.45 million shares.
Trading volume for the whole market was 13.6 million shares.
